title: Patrick Schiltz, an Ethicist, Is the Minnesota Judge Blasting ICE
summary: Judge Patrick Schiltz, an appointee of George W. Bush, became an unlikely critic of the Trump administration’s tactics in Minnesota.

title: How Battlefield Tech Was Used in Minneapolis
summary: Our reporter Thomas Gibbons-Neff, who deployed twice to Afghanistan as a Marine and later was our Kabul bureau chief, looks at the battlefield technology used for an immigration arrest at a home in Minneapolis.

title: Collins Took Credit for ICE Leaving Maine. Her Democratic Opponents Pounced.
summary: Political maneuvering by the Democrats hoping to unseat Senator Susan Collins shifted into high gear with the news that ICE had ended its surge there.

title: Venezuelan Lawmakers Approve Sweeping Overhaul of Oil Sector
summary: Bowing to Trump administration pressure, the new legislation improves conditions for foreign oil companies and opens the way to slash the taxes they pay.

title: Trump Warns Iran With Military Muscle, but Risks a Regional War
summary: Iran’s Islamic Republic, weakened by airstrikes in June and huge popular unrest, warns that it will strike back hard if attacked by the United States. This time, Iran may mean it.

title: How Trump’s 2020 Election Claims Have Been Debunked Again and Again
summary: The Trump administration has recently escalated its efforts to prove widespread voter fraud in 2020. Election officials and top Republicans have repeatedly said these claims are baseless.

title: Appeals Court Upholds TPS Protections for Venezuelans in the U.S.
summary: The Trump administration has sought to end Temporary Protected Status for more than a million people from troubled nations. About 600,000 are from Venezuela.

title: Trump Says He Only Appeared to Nod Off in Last Cabinet Meeting Because It Was ‘Boring’
summary: Mr. Trump’s allies have strenuously insisted that he was alert and attentive at the meeting last month. The president said he had only closed his eyes.

title: Kennedy Overhauls Federal Autism Panel in His Own Image
summary: The new panel, which advises the government on research and service priorities for people with autism, includes many members who have argued that vaccines cause the disorder.

title: ‘Melania,’ the Documentary, Premieres in Washington
summary: Amazon paid Melania Trump’s production company $40 million for the film and $35 million to promote it, a sum that critics said was an effort to curry favor with the administration.

title: Melania Trump Documentary Premiere: Who Turned Up to the Kennedy Center
summary: Top White House officials streamed into the Kennedy Center on Thursday to see Amazon’s new documentary about the first lady, Melania Trump.

title: Saks Fifth Avenue Bankruptcy Revives Debate Over the Future of Department Stores
summary: Saks Fifth Avenue’s bankruptcy filing has revived debates about how these once celebrated shopping emporiums can regain their luster.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens Despite Trump’s Tariffs
summary: The monthly trade deficit and imports rebounded in November after shrinking significantly in prior months, new data show.

title: Trump’s Trade Policies Sort Manufacturers Into Winners and Losers
summary: Tariffs have protected some companies, but more often they’ve hit the parts and materials many factories need to make finished goods.

title: Canada Signs Auto Deal With South Korea, Moving Further from the U.S.
summary: The agreement, while scarce on details, is the latest step by Prime Minister Mark Carney to reduce Canada’s reliance on trade with the U.S.

title: She Protested a Book Ban. Oklahoma Revoked Her Teacher’s License.
summary: Summer Boismier, a high school English teacher in Oklahoma,  lost her teaching license after she protested a book ban. Now she is fighting to return to the classroom.

title: Trump Says Putin Agreed to a Weeklong Pause in Attacks Amid Extreme Cold
summary: Russia has left thousands of apartment buildings in Kyiv without heat in recent weeks, in a campaign that has appeared aimed at breaking Ukraine’s morale.

title: Moscow Airport Sells for Half Off, a Sign of Russia’s Global Isolation
summary: The government opened the sale to cut-rate bidding for Domodedovo Airport after it received no offers at its initial asking price of $1.7 billion.

title: Pizza Cutter and a Fork: A Bizarre Bid to Break Mangione Out of Jail
summary: Federal prosecutors said a man was arrested after he impersonated an F.B.I. agent during a visit to the federal jail in Brooklyn where Luigi Mangione is being held.

title: Murdoch and News Corp Take on the West Coast with The California Post
summary: The expansion of the Murdoch tabloid from its New York roots to the West Coast is the latest sign of the outlet’s national ambitions.

title: Parents Navigate a Fracturing Vaccine Landscape
summary: Rattled by the C.D.C.’s actions and the spread of measles, some parents are scrambling to figure out how to best protect their children.

title: New Food Stamp Rules Are Confusing Grocery Stores and Consumers
summary: A dizzying array of rules govern what can be bought with SNAP dollars, confusing grocery stores and consumers.

title: How the A.I. Boom Could Push Up the Price of Your Next PC
summary: A.I. companies are buying up memory chips, causing the prices of those components — which are also used in laptops and smartphones — to soar.

title: California Jury Convicts Ex-Google Engineer of Stealing AI Secrets
summary: A federal jury found that Linwei Ding stole thousands of confidential files to help him start a company in Beijing.

title: One Solution for Too Many A’s? Harvard Considers Giving A+ Grades.
summary: Harvard University has been trying to cut back how many A grades professors give. Now, 53 percent of grades are A’s, down from 60 percent.

title: Genes May Control Your Longevity, However Healthily You Live
summary: A new study suggests that those with long-lived families probably have the best prospects of making it to a very old age.

title: The Polls Are Clear. Americans Don’t Want This.
summary: There is rising anxiety among Americans that the presence of an armed federal force in cities is actively making life less safe for people who live there.

title: Hind Rajab’s Mother: No Child Deserves to Die Like My Daughter
summary: What was done to my daughter did not break me. It left me with a mother’s responsibility to ensure no child is left unheard.

title: Democrats Reach a Deal With the White House
summary: Also, genes may determine longevity, a new study finds. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.

title: Maxim Naumov to Skate at 2026 Olympics After Parents’ Death in D.C. Plane Crash
summary: After his parents died in the midair collision over Washington, D.C., a year ago, Maxim Naumov struggled to put on his skates. Now he will compete for the United States at the Milan-Cortina Games.

title: Michael Beck, 65, Dies; First to Report Symptoms of ‘Havana Syndrome’
summary: As an employee with the N.S.A., he claimed he was exposed to a direct-energy device that led to a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease.

title: Costco Is Sued Over Preservatives in Its $5 Rotisserie Chickens
summary: A proposed class-action lawsuit claims Costco was misleading customers and engaging in false advertising when it described the chicken as having no preservatives.

title: Man Charged With Hate Crimes After He Rams Car Into Chabad Headquarters
summary: The police accused a New Jersey man of slamming his vehicle into the Hasidic Jewish organization’s Brooklyn headquarters. The man’s father said that his son wanted to convert to Judaism.
